topic.title: HELP SAVE THE INTERNET!
topic.body:
Congress is voting to [kill the internet](https://act.eff.org/action/don-t-let-congress-undermine-our-online-privacy)...again. But we stand a chance of stopping it!

This is really important. If you live here in 'Murica, **Call your representatives!** 

If you need help finding them, there is the official site here: http://www.house.gov/representatives/find/

And a much simpler one here, which also lets you contact your rep in-browser: https://callyourreps.arcology.io/

Again, **I Can't stress how important this is.** Please, do it! Even if you are terrified of speaking to people, one more voice is better than none!

And regardless of if you even live here or not: spread the word! We can't let this go down without a fight!

topic.title: [PSA] Help Preserve Climate Data!
topic.body:
Trump's regime is trying to erase decades worth of climate data. A huge number of scientists and activists are trying to rescue as much as possible--but *you can help too!*

Look [here](https://www.datarefuge.org/) for more info. In a week or two when I have the time, I'm planning on writing something that can use the CKAN api to auto-publish some of it on zeronet (I may need help). 

 Also, If you have a torrent client and storage/bandwidth to spare, there are [torrent backups](https://climate.daknob.net/) to distribute--Weather you can permaseed or just reach a ratio of 1.1, it'll help!

3_1BRSETd8x5XUtHt9jz2e4WdB9rWY1WNfiu.body:
CSS isn't too hard, and you can pick up [some](http://www.w3schools.com/css/css3_backgrounds.asp) of the simpler parts pretty easily.

As an example, this bit changes all buttons to have a [yellow](http://www.colorhexa.com/fff400) background and white border when hovered over:

``
.button:hover {background-color: #FFF400; border-color: white}
``

For a background, you want to find ``body`` (ctrl-f for huge files) and change the [color](http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_colors.asp) listed there.

I tried finding it for the ~~main page's~~ this talk page's css file (better example) and it's on line 111 (`body { background-color: #F5F5F5;`). This is the greyish background here.
You're welcome. Also, [here](https://learnxinyminutes.com/docs/css/) is another nice little rundown.

These are the alternatives I can think of at the moment:

1. A rolling blockchain/pruning, where a fixed amount of the last X transactions/ days are kept. Can also be set up so that storing more than the minimum is possible (and clients are rewarded for doing so).

2. [Whatever the hell MaidSafe is doing](https://safe-network-explained.github.io/safe-for-bitcoiners#blockchain).

3. Tangles: A new structure Invented by [IOTAtoken](http://iotatoken.com/). They're like a blockchain, but not strictly linear. The whitepaper is [here](http://iotatoken.com/IOTA_Whitepaper.pdf).

26_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv.body:
> [kai0](#comment_32_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): I think it is wrong to consider the P2P network formed by the mobile now. Because the mobile's storage capacity is too small.

People use a lot of mobile devices, and being able to use Zeronet on them would make people like it more. Also, streaming data instead of downloading is becoming more popular (like Netflix/Spotify/Youtube), so being able to do some amount of that is a good idea too.

> For example, from 100000 personal computers constitute zeronet basic network, each computer to take 30G hard drive capacity, 100000X30G = 3000T. So big a P2P database, how to build? How to run How to maintain This is the real problem.

That example isn't totally right. A network can be very redundant, or have high capacity, but having more of one means having less of the other. You can have more of each, but that's much harder. ([this page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAP_theorem) explains it a little more).

For example, if there was only one site with a size of 30GB, then the whole network can only store 30GB. I know it's not really like that--but in the real network, just adding up the storage of each device isn't correct.

> [kai0](#comment_34_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): everything is done。

[It really isn't](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Aenhancement). A better foundation is easier to build on top of.

There are people that have [already](http://createjs.org) made [CMSes](https://cdmedia.github.io/cms.js/) with Javascript, and it's possible to adapt one of those to use here. I know at least one [person](/126fBtopb2n7Pc42KhZyZyHhZKrecAdMdR) has already tried this.

> [kai0](#comment_38_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): I don't know css at all, to hard for me to change it.

Consider learning [a bit](https://www.w3schools.com), it can be fun.

This is a little hard though, because "making it look pretty" is something graphical designers are better at, and "making it do things" is what programmers are best at (It's like having one person who is an expert on making sculptures, and one who is an expert on painting them). Nofish seems good at both, which is kind of rare. I don't think many other developers here are good at both skills.
I'll also see if I can do something with it over the weekend, but there's only some much I can do unless I have more information. Maybe make a simple picture of what you're thinking of?
